title: RUDIMENTA LINGVAE LATINAE
author: Eugenio Pace
excerpt: Latin is often called a "dead language." In the sense that people don’t normally use it for everyday conversations—except maybe in the Vatican.
excerptPlain: Latin is often called a _"dead language."_ In the sense that people don’t normally use it for everyday conversations—except maybe in the Vatican.

title: LECTIO PRIMA (First Declension Nouns)
author: Eugenio Pace
excerpt: Nouns (et. Nomen: name) is the name we give to things, people, and places; either generally (the city, the man), or specifically (Seattle, Marcus).
excerptPlain: *Nouns* (et. *Nomen*: name) is the name we give to things, people, and places; either generally (the city, the man), or specifically (Seattle, Marcus).

title: LECTIO SECUNDA (Second Declension - Masculine)
author: Eugenio Pace
excerpt: Second declensions nouns are mostly masculine and neuter. Like first declension nouns, there's a base and endings for each case. Most ,masculine 2nd declensions nouns end in the (familiar) us. Many (masculine) names end in us too: Marcus, Aurelius, Lucius. Names, like any noun also decline, which I find neat.
excerptPlain: Second declensions nouns are mostly masculine and neuter. Like first declension nouns, there's a base and endings for each case. Most ,masculine 2nd declensions nouns end in the (familiar) **us**. Many (masculine) names end in **us** too: _Marcus_, _Aurelius_, _Lucius_. Names, like any noun _also_ decline, which I find neat.

title: LECTIO TERTIA (Second Declension - Neuter)
author: Eugenio Pace
excerpt: Neuter nouns are plenty in the 2nd declension. Their Nominative end in -um. Nominative plural for the neuter is -a which can be easily confused with the (femenine) First Declension. Watch out!
excerptPlain: Neuter nouns are plenty in the 2nd declension. Their Nominative end in **-um**. Nominative plural for the neuter is **-a** which can be easily confused with the (femenine) First Declension. Watch out!

title: SALVETE DISCIPVLI
author: Eugenio Pace
excerpt: Years ago, I decided to study Latin. I had many reasons, but the main ones were:
